content:
Posted: April 12, 2014
												Given how frequently new instalments in the Call of Duty and Battlefield series are churned out, there's a risk that the gaming world will soon grow tired of the military shooter. As enjoyable as these titles can be, some are starting to feel the genre is growing stale. Sniper Elite V2 is a game that could potentially set that right, offering a refreshingly tactical take on warfare simulation.Rebellion Developments has strived to plant players directly in the shoes of a frontline sniper with this third-person shooter. It's all about moving around in the shadows, creating diversions and calculating the perfect shot down to the finest detail. The game will certainly find favour with those who value realism over arcade action, but it's not for everyone.Sniper Elite V2 is essentially a reimagining of its 2005 predecessor, set within the same time frame, with a different spin on events. The game takes place in a battle-ravaged Berlin in the closing days of World War II, with players controlling a US officer dropped into the city to stop the Russians from poaching the Nazi's top scientists.The storyline runs only surface-deep, though newsreel-style cut scenes and effective voice acting help capture the Zeitgeist of war-torn Europe. In-game backdrops aren't too shabby either. Those rubble-strewn streets and burnt out buildings look glorious at the higher resolutions, and are functional environments where gameplay is concerned.Missions see players venture behind enemy lines on their lonesome, with only their wits and arsenal as allies. It starts out stealthy and tense as you creep by enemy patrols in search of a suitable vantage point to pick off your target from. Infiltration is a delicate game, and once your sniper's cover is blown, you're unlikely to last very long. A submachine gun, a silenced pistol and a trusty sniper rifle are the tools of your trade, although other weapons can be picked up later on. There's also a range of explosives on offer that must be used tactically if you want to get out of war-torn Berlin alive. Trip mines can be affixed to the threshold of a doorway to cover your escape, while proximity mines are useful for booby trapping enemy corpses.Every step you take and every bullet you fire must be carefully calculated in Sniper Elite V2. If you're not fleeing from the scene of an assassination, you'll either be crouch-walking or crawling along the ground since loud footsteps give away your position. This will certainly make the game a no-go for those who prefer swifter-paced action affairs, but as far as the stealth fans are concerned, it's an authentic experience.Firing stray shots from cover to create a diversion usually pays dividends, as do shrewd takedowns with a silenced pistol bullet. The idea is to come and go like the wind, never giving away your location.Infiltration is an integral part of the game, but the assassination set pieces are the meat of the experience. Finding the perfect spot to take aim from is only half the battle. There are a lot of variables to take into account when pulling off the perfect shot, such as distance, wind resistance, and even your rate of exhalation.Pulling off an effective kill gives rise to an immense feeling of satisfaction, heightened by the bullet-cam depiction of your handiwork, which shows your target's internal organs being ruptured via an x-ray effect.While these segments show off Sniper Elite V2 at its very best, they also highlight one of its biggest drawbacks. While enemy AI can be lethal if you blow your cover, its movement patterns and behaviour are thoroughly predictable. Picking them off from a safe distance is not unlike shooting fish in a barrel. Even on the higher difficulty settings where guard patrols will come at you in force, their attack strategy is enough to make one of Darth Vader's stormtroopers blush.The solo campaign offers around 10 hours of gameplay, and can be played co-operatively online to pad it out further. A selection of multiplayer modes provides further mileage, along with some unique twists on the military shooter formula. Overwatch mode is the standout offering, casting one player in the role of a sniper providing support for a ground level companion as they complete a range of objectives.In closing, Sniper Elite V2 does a lot of things right. The tactical components have been well thought out, despite predictable enemy AI upsetting the balance somewhat. Minor issues aside, headshot enthusiasts and stealth fans will find much to love here.

Pros-The sniping mechanics are really good. The game takes into account bullet drop, wind, stance (whether you are crouching, laying down or standing), breath and motion.-The game lets you tackle a level the way you want to. You are only given a waypoint and how you reach that waypoint is up to you.-The levels are fairly open. Most levels have several big “arenas” connected by corridors.-The A.I can be quite challenging...Cons-The A.I can also be very dumb at times. I saw a couple of times enemies just giving up and resuming their normal route right after they had spotted me or I had killed someone next to them-Some minor bugs-At times the enemy can spot you behind cover or behind boxes which can be frustrating when you have successfully sneaked past several enemies.Neutral-Rebellion has been updating the game with “advertising” for their other Sniper Elite games. Now at the start of the game there is a launcher that is just one advert for their newer game and when closing the game there is another advert that you have to manually quit.I found Sniper Elite V2 to be quite an enjoyable experience. The gameplay is good and can accommodate any type of player (whether you run and gun, use stealth or anything in between), the story while not being anything remarkable is enjoyable and the mission structure is good enough to keep you playing. Sniper Elite is a fun game and an easy one to recommend.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												The game is unlike anything else on the market, it is becoming and will become a cult classic just like I predicted when I reviewed this game a few days after the release (the Nazi Zombie expansion packs attest to that)  There are only three major negatives about this game that I can think of:1) It is not as immersive and complex as the first game;2) The enemy AI could be improved, but its not terrible;3) The game could be harder.I've been playing this game practically non-stop since it came out.There are certainly some trade-offs for the negatives. The graphics have been improved over the first game, obviously. The Asura engine is now one of my favorite engines, it shined in Aliens Vs. Predator and it's pretty good here. Except I don't understand why the last AVP game had Directx 11 support and this game doesn't. That is kind of inconsistent on the part of Rebellion. The bullet ballistics are still pretty good although they have been made easier since the first game. After a pretty fast learning curve you will be able to snipe targets away pretty easily. So I do kind of wish that it could be harder to snipe targets, for the better kill satisfaction. The graphics are pretty decent, I just with the anti-aliasing applied to every jaggy out there.The X-ray slow-mo camera. You can shoot your enemy's gonads off, you can shoot their jaw off, you can destroy their rib cages, their kidneys, their heart, their lungs, their eyes. The skull can also be destroyed in many ways even when the enemy is wearing a helmet. You just never get tired of it. I am frankly surprised that other shooting games haven't attempted this before and it is 2012!The physics of the game are pretty good. There is plenty of destruction to go around. What I also loved is that if you make your character sit and then start slowly rotating the camera view either left or right, you will actually see your character chance stance by turning the torso and moving the legs. It just FEELS that you are controlling someone. Compare that with Skyrim's third person view. When you do the same thing in that game, your character will just start levitating in air without shuffling legs or changing the body position.The bullet ballistics are good but can get predictable. If you miss your first shot from afar, you can immediately adjust your aim to shoot either slightly to the left or to the right, depending on where the last bullet hit.The online co-op campaign, something that is missing in so many games, thanks for not having an emblem for that, gamespot. My buddy and I spent hours carefully going through the 11 NON-RECYCLED AND VARIOUS missions. Not only that, there is a horde mode, or the Kill Tally mode, (only 2 players), with 10 waves and an increasing amount of enemies plus enemy trucks, jeeps, halftracks and tiger tanks (last wave only). There are 3 maps for that, each with plenty of locations to hide and hold your ground. You can plant trip wires, mines, dynamite. You can also self ignite enemy vehicles by shooting their fuel tank. You can also kill two or three enemies at a time with one bullet and even kill them with ricochet when they are hiding. There is also a bombing run mode, where you and your partner attempt to collect auto parts for fixing a vehicle and extracting. It is much harder than Kill Tally. There is also an overwatch mode (3 maps only) wherein you and your partner can either play as a sniper or the attacker conducting the ground assault. Finally, there is team deathmatch, with 2 new additional maps that were just added by Rebellion a couple of days ago.The story is okaish but damn is it made up, straight out of Inglorious Basterds. You are an American (of course) sniper in Berlin in April 1945 (yeah right), killing Germans and....Russians (with American bullets, ooookay), who is supposed to stop the Russian launch of captured V-2 rockets with poisonous gas on London as a prelude for the Cold War. It's preposterous if you have any respect for history.There is a lack of stealth in the game. I mean you could do it in about half the missions but it's more fun just shooting ze Germans and ze Russkies. Whenever you decide to go stealth, make sure to snipe targets during a loud sound as to not alert nearby enemies. You can also search your slain enemies for the ammo and supplies. You can also pick them up and hide them. As you progress, you find new weapons that you can later use in multiplayer but there aren't that many of them.The sound is good. There are distant explosions in the background, there are low and high altitude planes flying. There isn't a single civilian in the entire game though.The enemies could use some work. They aren't terrible though. They shoot, they take cover, they change positions, they zigzag, they throw grenades, they pick up and treat their fallen comrades. The snipe from afar and CHANGE THEIR SNIPING POSITIONS. The only real thing that I would have liked is for them to stick to their cover for longer times if they are being shot at by the sniper. The slowing down of time is neat, but it makes the game super easy. That technique is meant for the controller, since you can't aim as well with the two sticks.Finally, this is a great game if you are looking for something fresh. I can only hope that Rebellion adds a map editor. There are just so many scenarios to invent here.  The game is somewhat innovative, fun and pretty solid.All in all, awesome game. Go ahead and support Rebellion. They have redeemed themselves after AVP.

Posted: April 28, 2014
												First time I write a review here, so I might as well write it proper.As I see it, Sniper Elite falls between a number of chairs. It tries to have it's cake and eat it too, and suffers greatly due to it. It's part stealth, part action and long range focused. Problem is, there is no good way of planning attacks, the gameplay is linear and the sheer number of enemies makes this game in a much poorer condition than it could have been in.The offset is pretty good. There aren't alot of games that focuses on the role of the sniper/marksman out there, and so far nobody has really suceded in recreating that aspect of combat. The game tries to come off as realistic, having it's balistic model as one of it's most adverticed selling points. And to some extent, the bullet physics are great, exept bullets can't penetrate anything, even a wooden fence can stop these bullets. Only thing it actually does penetrate are foilage and bodyparts... the latter it doess rather well.The levels of the game does not invite the player to plan their attacks, as I stated earlier. In addition, there is far to much focus on close quarters combat for this to really take the art of sniping seriously. Snipers and marksmen are mainly covert operators, and they are usually only used for high value target and recon, not as the one man army portrayed in this game. The gameplay is repetative, unintuitive and plain booring in the long run, and it's far from as interesting as it could have been.It does, however, provide some entertainment if you have nothing else to do for 30 minutes, but as a game to sit down and enjoy for an evening, it doesn't serve at all.Hope that you'll find this review helpful, comments are welcome.

Posted: October 27, 2014
												Got this free on Steam. You should have done so too. This isn't entirely realistic, but it's one of those games which strikes a balance between realism and fun. It's challenging too. The story, however, is not very engaging. You are an OSS agent in WWII trying to assassinate German scientists before the Russians can get them, so not only will you fight German soldiers, but also Soviet soldiers. And there's was a lot of room to make a decent story; you are a secret agent carrying out missions that "never happened" after all. But anyway, on the the gameplay itself. As said already, it's great. Since you are a sniper, close combat is discouraged, and even though you have an SMG, it has limited ammo. For the best experience, I recommend you set the enemy skill to "Veteran", realism to "limited", and tactical assistance "off". Lower settings to me make the game too easy. That said, you have to praise Rebellion for making customizable difficulties. And the main feature of the game: the X-ray cam. It show just what a sniper bullet can do to your body. Can be quite satisfying, especially when fighting difficult enemies. This is cinematics done right. Fortunately, if you are squeamish, you can turn it off. Also, never underestimate a single foe: he can kill you easily. Speaking of the enemies, while they can pose a challenge, the AI could use some improving. This is evident when you see German and Soviet soldiers fighting each other; they will have no problem trying to kill you, but they seem to not cope well when fighting each other. The campaign has a decent length: 8-10 hours. And a second play-through is worth it. Multiplayer is quite fun too, you are all snipers. Element of surprise and awareness play an even bigger role here.So do I recommend this game? Yes. But you should have got it when it was free. Right now, it's $30, and I don't think that's a good price. If you didn't get a free copy, wait for a sale: this game is worth $20 to me.

Posted: June 9, 2014
												I really wish I could recommend Sniper Elite V2... but I just can't. Which is weird because it's a game I enjoyed playing a lot.Let's start with the good things. Like many said before me, the sniping mechanics are incredibly well done. Sure, some would argue that you shouldn't have to adjust your scopes for a 100m shot, but the maps are relatively small, so it's kind of necessary to have such a drastic bullet drop in this game. It makes the gameplay more challenging and definitely more fun... and that's just the ballistics. The bullet cam and the X-ray vision are what make this game very unique. I don't think I've ever enjoyed sniping so much before.BUTThese surprisingly fun sniper-sections of the game aren't worth the 20€ you'd be spending on it. (Thank god I got it for free...) Why, you may ask? Because not only the campaign lasts only like 6 hours at most (played on the highest difficulty, which is the only way I would recommend playing this game), only half of it will be spent sniping like that. Which should be okay since you don't want to get bored, obviously. Variety is important you may say, but sniping is literally the only thing they got right in this game... and after an hour of gameplay, you're gonna wish you could just snipe from your safe vantage point again, instead of attempting to sneak through an army of enemies, then inevitably fail.You may have guessed by now that this game is supposed to be a stealth-based one. A mixture of sneaking your way through to the objective, then assasinate X and hunt the rest of the enemies nearby. That's how it should work.Guess what: it doesn't. Most of the time you're given a very linear map which is almost completely impossible to sneak through. There are other times where no matter how good you are, you literally can't be stealthy: as soon as you arrive to a checkpoint, you trigger waves of enemies coming at you, no matter how sneaky you are. Then you're left there alone, against hundreds(!) of commies or Jerries with your trusted sniper rifle... and nothing else, since your SMG is♥♥♥♥♥♥weak and carries up to 2 magazines at once, and your pistol is either used for stealth play (which is either useless or non-existent most of the time), or you could grab a Colt and attempt to benefit from the power of the .45ACP round and its rate of fire. Good luck with that.So the game forces you to snipe even in a CQB situation, which is absolutely ridiculous. You better grab your Gewehr 43.Even when stealth play is given, you'll just find it faster, more effective and more fun to shoot your way through the enemies anyway. The other features of the game (setting up traps for your enemy, using distraction, the controls, storyline, co-op and multiplayer) are either laughably bad or just plain useless.TL;DR: Fun sniping, bad everything else. Worth it if it's free, not worth it if you have to pay for it.5/10 for the amazing sniping parts

												This game is not a bad game, and its built on a solid premise, but theres quite a bit that the other reviewers do not tell about. So please read this knowing that it only means to highlight some things about the game. First off, this is a sniping sim played through a third person shooter lense, but it is not "Realistic" its "Arcade" The most you can have is wind and gravity, for many gamers this is much more than their normal sniping experience, but it is still very watered down. The game plays in one of two ways, either its "Stealth mode" where you get a little indicator that bombs are falling and can cover the sound of your shooting, or you basically play zombie survival with enemy soldiers, every ten feet a new wave comes. Its not very sniper-y, youll spend most of the game in the streets of Germany, where no one with half a brain would stick around (as in no sneaking into buildings or picking your path, the game forces it on you)Another important point is there is almost no sniper versus sniper strategy. You die in two shots from an enemy sniper, so poke your head out, take the shot, learn where they are, wait 15 seconds for your health to come back, peek back out and empty your clip in their direction. If theres more than one sniper, youll die in the two shots and have to restart the spot hoping that the random sniper spawn changes. The enemy snipers also spawn at predetermined times, so you cannot look through your scope at the next area looking for enemies, you literally HAVE to walk in and get shot at to find them in almost every situation. Again, the game is not bad, its a great sniper game for people who think basic wind and gravity are "Hard". The story also is not bad, it's a ww2 setting so it's hard to stand out but it manages to keep ones attention. Overall, it's good for a few hours of fun. The sniping, especially in the stealth portions, is fun, and the killcam part makes it more exciting to get crazy kills like Richochets or long distance headshots. That being said, the distances you shoot at with the rifles you use, in reality, would have very little if any bullet drop.The longest shot i took thus far was about 5 blocks away. Review is still positive because what the game promises is there, and it is fun! But keep in mind what you are buying, this is not a hardcore snipers game, this is an arcade style ww2 shooter. When the game wants you to be stealthy, it lets you know, when it doesnt, you dont have the choice to be.

												I actually have been playing this series in an odd order. I completed SE3 first, then SE1 (Wasn't into it with it first came out, but recently became fond of it, probably after seeing what they did to it with V2 and 3), and now am wading through SE2. I liked SE3 quite a bit, it was a lot of fun, but my main gripe with it was the braindead AI and broken stealth mechanics. Which still exists here. But the upside was that SE2 was a bit more of a playground, and the AI were slightly more aggressive.So in Sniper Elite V2, you obviously play as a sniper, but you don't really feel like one at all. It just feels like it's on rails to me. Most often, the best thing to do when you see enemies is to just sit and one spot and shoot all of them. Yeah, even with the difficulty and realism settings on max. You don't even have to be good at it, honestly, just wait for your health to come back and pop out to rapid-fire snipe them until it hits them. Though there is a lot of reward to get headshots and vital shots without the diamond aim assist. With the aim assist you just get to feel badass.But sitting in one place for five minutes is bad, right? No, the AI (even at the highest difficulty) don't really do anything that forces you to move. You never need to set up traps like they show you in the tutorial, you'll barely get any good chances to use them. They lack the ability to perform fire-and-movement tactics, or flanking maneuvers, and grenades are easily dealt with by walking backwards. Just inch your gun out from behind cover to where nobody can shoot you, but you can shoot them. That's it. If they get too close you can just use iron sights on your rifle, or throw a grenade (they won't run away from them). All of the submachine guns are worthless (you're more likely to die using them than you are killing anyone with them). I haven't tried any pistol except for the Welrod, with its gloriously inaccurate 6-round magazine, so if they are any good I am unaware of it. Welrod is nice though. Even if you fail the miserable stealth system, just shoot them three times in a row with the welrod to kill, and no matter how much yelling they make, it won't attract anyone. It just stunlocks them. Actually, it doesn't seem like ANYTHING the AI says influences their fellow soldiers. Their speech is just empty, like only you can hear it.Speaking of stealth, it's simple. Don't be seen, don't be heard. Well, often times falling a short distance (maybe a foot off of some object, this is a normal thing when proceeding through the level) will cause some horrendous noise that alerts enemies half a block away from you, causing them all to walk around awkwardly shouting "I know you're here, sniper!!" "Sniper no sniping!!" "What was that!? A sniper?!". Yet shooting someone that is just a foot away from someone facing the opposite direction, having them scream and gasp and fall to the ground, will not alert them...this is exactly the problem I had experienced in SE3, and I get this crap in almost every level.Another thing, which is kind of interesting, is that there are some environmental noises that can mask your gunshot. But..it doesn't really make sense. Your gunshot is only masked if YOU are in range of the object that masks your noise. An enemy could be by a noise source and hear everything going on. But if you stand by a noise source and a bullet whizzes right past their face, they aren't going to notice a thing. Nope. Not even if it hits the wall right beside them.One time, I think it was the third level, in the underground factory or whatever it was, I had a big firefight on one of the big hallways. Of course all I had to do was crouch behind a table and shoot all six of those nazis. Despite all of their hollering and return fire, I walk into one of the side corridors, not even 10 meters away from a dead nazi, and there's a guy just peacefully walking along as if he didn't notice a thing.So basically, I don't know what anyone was expecting from these sequels. But I was coming to this hoping for an awesome, gritty, realistic, stealth-sniping game, and if you want that you can give SE1 a try, it's not great but it's good (really dated, might not be an issue for other gamers). What I got was more like a light gun shooter. This game could've been great, but everything about how the AI reacts to the player made it go all wrong. SE3 is better, but still has the same problems. And I'll probably get SE4 too just because it's supposed to be even more sandboxy.

												First "Sniper Elite" titled game from Rebellion was disgustingly bad. It was pretentious, sure, and it created some vile fan community... But it was awful all over. Yet, it was upgraded, and it evolved into something better! "Sniper Elite" V2 isn't horrendous game, like V1. Now it's just silly. Sure, there is some "unique" charm, made by combination of intrusive usage of sniper rifles, with kinda tricky "almost realistic" ballistic part, and slow-mo "x-ray bullet cam" effect. Which is literally provokes people to make shot after shot, again and again, and see another dummy's brain or testicles splattered.But, again, all over it's just another silly game about World War II made by people who know nothing about it and don't give a shoot about it. And made for people alike, with carefully cultivated by the gaming industry bad taste for lame on-rail scripted shooters.What were the worst points in the Sniper V1? By gameplay terms, in the first place, the shooting was bad. All the weaponry in hands of player besides the main rifle, was nerfed up to no use. V2 saved that feature, as one of its own personality markings, but still, other guns now are slightly more useful. To the point when I'm able to do some room cleaning without long and clumsy scoped boomstick. Not good enough, yeah, but way better than it was.Next, the AI. Now, the player and his enemies are learned to take covers, and even walk around corners from different sides! Sure, they're still dummies, blindly running forward on your position, even on the hardest difficulty setting. Eagle-eyed snipers, who can peek you from great distance in one place, but will neglect your presence in close-combat range, are also there. The "stealth" part is also spoiled from the start to the end of the game - you'll never need that, anyway. Except for two optional achievements, in the DLCs "St.Pierre" and "Neudorf Outpost". But, but, all in all, AI is surely much more complicated than in the V1, and has some fairplay tricks to make you feel oppressed, at least in some moments. Respawning-stormtroopers-on-your-back cliche is still widely in use, sure. But now you can make some traps on your way, which seems kinda useful in some dire situations where you're supposed to hold the point for some time against hordes of enemies. That part was even kinda hilarious. But not all that useful, alas!The other bad part of Sniper V1 were level maps. There was about 5 of them for 28 "missions"... And they were poorly made, for the most part. Except maybe, occasionally, there was a place to perform a shot for more than 300 meters range. In the Sniper V2, there are 10 maps for 11 game missions (+some dlc's, each is 1 new map for 1 new mission, usually). Each map in the V2 is usually covered in an half of an hour... Yeah, the maps are That Short. They're looking not bad overall, but it's all the same - narrow corridor, with the ability to walk around some house from one side or another - at most. So, the marketing passages about "Sniper's choice" and "using the Environment"  are about the "hide behind chest-high wall and squeeze the trigger as you please". Since the maps are quite short, I doubt that many players will ever achieve range above 350-400 meters (except the very last shot of the game, which is not skill-based, by all means).Finally, the story and player's motivation. In the first game, the player was an American agent in '45 Berlin, dressed as german paramilitary, and killing soviet soldiers before they dig up some really dirty nazi secrets. In the second game, the scenario is slightly more evasive. Now, the Russians are not the targets just because they are Russians and Commies, and whatever. No, there they're planning to shoot the V2 rocket armed with some nerve gas from Berlin straight to London (3 times of its actual range) and pretend it was Nazies! And actual Nazies who made the rockets and the gas - are helping the Soviets with the attack! To make Germany's reparations even higher, supposedly. Yeah, I guess people who've bought CoD Black Ops will buy any kind of crud, coming as a "history-based scenario". Why not the Soviets bombing their Allies? Because that's what evil tyrants like Stalin always do, right? Or not? Oh, who cares! Just pop more heads and see their brains exploded, that's what this game about!Finally, before I set my mark, I'll say a few words about multiplayer there. It is always a room full of campers, isn't that great? Well, I know some good shooters where some maps are made for this kind of self-entertainment... But to make all the multiplayer around campers is surely extreme way of thinking. Even the fact that ballistic there, with bullet derivation and all that, in reality looks quite arcade and dumbed down... Well, like I said from the beginning, the game is silly and stupid. And better than the first one. And aimed to some blood-thirsty 13-years-old maniacs who're not caring about whom to shoot, or why.Mark is 6/10. And downvote, for it's all still not fun enough.

Posted: April 23, 2014
												This game is a sad waste of potential, just like everything else that comes out of Rebellion. There's a wonderful ballistics model, and the kill-cam is really nice, but the rest of the game is an awful slog. You're given a handful of items, none of which will ever be helpful. Your silenced pistol is too inaccurate to use beyond literally a few in-game feet. If you're hiding outside a doorway and your enemy is on the other side of the room, you've got maybe a 30% chance of hitting his head. You won't want to aim anywhere else, hitting him anywhere else just sets him off. Rocks will trigger enemies, but can distract them for about a half-second. I haven't ever used them because if I'm that close and they don't know I'm there, I'd rather just shoot them with the pistol. I won't touch on the SMG, it's so inaccurate and has so little ammo that they might as well have ignored it. You're better off spamming your rifle, stunlocking with the pistol, or more likely just letting them murder you so that you can restart.I hear rumors about things known as "stealth" and "flanking", though I've never seen them nor have I ever seen an opportunity for them to manifest. That's not a lack of skill, there's just no other path to take. The first level is within a bombed-out city, which means that there are a handful of buildings you can go in, and everything else is invisible walls and rubble. There is one path winding through the streets, and you have to walk through the open in order to get to the next objective. The first two missions might as well have been on rails for all the freedom you're given. Waypoints and invisible walls push you ever forward, you're never given any reason nor opportunity to place traps on enemies, move bodies you've shot, or otherwise use the level organically. This issue is compounded by the fact that the enemies will spawn in and re-arrange themselves spontaneously depending on your "progress". This means that you'll pretty much never be able to place TNT as traps, you can only trigger them by shooting them. In order to use it as a trap, you'd have to manually place it next to an enemy, then backtrack to a vantage point and trigger the explosives. In lieu of that you could just shoot the enemy from the vantage point and skip the middleman, or sneak up on the enemy and use the silenced pistol. However, the latter option is likely to trigger enemy rearrangements or spontaneous reinforcements as you approach. Enemies are super-eagle-eyed, so you can forget about sneaking around within 100 feet of an enemy unless they're scripted to stare away from you forever until shot. That could change as you get closer, they could spontaneously shift into a patrol route because you passed through an invisible trigger. The awareness indicator is low to the ground, hard to see, and if it's there you've pretty much already tipped them off to your location. This goes double for snipers, who spawn in only when you're about to blindly encounter them, and they are set up so that they will always immediately spot you and engage. If you manage to cheat the detection system through a combination of luck and respawn-based clairvoyance, that still makes them the first target you *have* to shoot in order to progress. On the second level, they're placed so that they can't see you, but that's only so that you can exploit the noise mechanic. The noise mechanic doesn't care about ambient sounds, there's an indicator that pops up when specific events happen (like a train horn), and during that interval you can do *anything* without drawing attention. At all other times, every spawned enemy will hear every shot, and all nearby enemies will track upright footsteps. While enemies are eagle-eyed, they are forgetful. If you're lucky no one has Line of Sight to you and you can wait the minute or so that it takes for all the enemies to assume you've given up and gone home. Be prepared to use and abuse this feature.My suggestion is to download the demo. If you enjoyed blowing people's brains out, play the level again. That's the level right after the tutorial, copied entirely. It never gets better than that level right there. The maps are just as restrictive, the enemies spawn/rearrange spontaneously in the same "just to F*ck with you" maner, and the objectives are never more than "go here", "plant the thing" or "shoot the guy". I don't blame you for enjoying the shooting, I certainly did. There's just no reason to purchase the full game. No other part of the experience is worth the investment, if you're only there for the shooting than you might as well stick with the demo that lets you shoot stuff for free. If someone's done a Let's Play of this game from start to finish, you should just watch that and be done with it. You can't play this game any other way, the only variable would be your personal shooting performance. To simulate that, I refer you back to the demo.

												Hrnngh/10If you already have it, you should give it a punt. You should maybe buy it on sale or something. But it's definitely not a full price purchase, as far as I'm concerned. It tries do to curious stuff, but fails more often than not. There's some nice verticality to the level design at times, and I like how it discourages close quarter combat by making you vulnerable and letting you carry a pitiful amount of submachine gun ammo. There's also a level where you're caught in a crossfire between the Germans and the Russians, having to fend off waves of soldiers from both sides while you slowly claim ground towards your target. It is The Acest Thing.At times, Sniper Elite is an amazing powertrip. I once had three enemies in close proximity - one patroling, and two standing guard. I took one of the static ones out, masking my shot with the ringing of a church bell. While the patroling soldier was examining the body, I took the other surviving guy out in a similar way. As the sole survivor turned around, he found another dead body, having no clue what was happening. I like to think he was pretty bewildered as a speeding bullet entered his skull.Ultimately, I spent a lot of time carefully planning a stealthy infiltration, stealthy assasination and stealthy exfiltration that never was. The checkpoints were too far apart to restart every time I was noticed, and I was noticed far more often than I would've liked. The thing is, I feel like it wasn't really my fault most of the time. The conveniently loud artillery fire would misteriously cease indefinitely as soon as I picked off my first target. Enemy reinforcements would magically appear in places I've already sweeped. Cheap stuff like that.I had fun for a couple of hours, but I came close to giving up on it several times.

												A average, maybe even decent game and with the little amount of sniper games available, it might be worth it. But for me, the bad definitely outweighed the good and I often got tired of it or dropped it for a while out of frustration, not at least with the terrible autosave system. If you buy it cheap on sale (personally I got it for free in a short promotion offer on steam), it isn't a waste, but the money could be used so much better and for an older (and short) game it is quite expensive.The good:- Quite good sniper mechanics including wind and bullet drop (meaning that you often have to fire a bit over and to the left of the target to hit it, which is realistic).- Kill cam shows you the bullet penetrating your target in x-ray.- You can hit grenades in enemy belts and make them explode.- Graphics are quite good.The bad:- The third person looks provide you with a hell of a camera angle, often meaning that you can't see an enemy if he's right in front of you and you are standing close to a wall.- No real training possibilities meaning you need to practice shooting on the go. This is a problem in a sniper games as it means that you will newer really master how to hit a far away target precisely where you want to, that is, to calibrate the wind and bullet drop. At least not until you are almost finished with the game anyway.- The autosave is very bad and means some place that you might need to play through half an hour of combat again if you die. Also, to me it seems like some places, the enemies kept coming closer and closer every time I restarted at checkpoint giving me very little time to react and therefore dying a lot of times.- There is a general lack of genuine good sniping positions. Most positions are of the kind where you would be dead in five minutes in real life. In real life, a good sniping position is NOT sitting behind a small box in the middle of the road, but a place where you can fire without being spotted and then move to another good sniping position before you fire again. This is more or less impossible in this game.- While stealth is a possibility, most parts of the game more or less enforce you to chose between rambo or rambo-ligth approaches. A real sniper doesn't stand in one position blasting down 15 enemy soldiers firing in on him or assaulting a compound with a submachine gun killing off 50 soldiers.- There should be a more realistic game mode whit less help for when you want a challenge. In this you should be able to set off your own landmines and trip-mines if you don't pay attention to where you put them and there shouldn't be bullet lines to help you spot where people are shooting at you from.- The plot is bad and extremely right-wing USA coldwar hawkish. You fight to liberate nazi war criminals as long at they will help the USA build weapons or kill them if they want to do the same for the USSR. You don't assist in winning the war, on the contrary you actually delays the advance of the Red Army thereby prolonging the war and the suffering of both soldiers and civilians in the war zone or living in areas still under nazi control. Actually, you even kills lots of allied soldiers of the red army.- There are a few bucks in the game, but when they happen, they are major. Like a wagon full of German soldiers not moving at all while I stand right next to it killing them one by one.- There is no real aiming with other weapons than the sniper riffle, no real use of iron-sight but instead a cross point with a large spread of bullets, even at very close range .... like 1 meter.- The game is too split up in "zones". Meaning that you can't really lure most enemies away from the small area they start in. It would be cool if you could fire at them, luring them to follow you into a building which you had filled with traps offering you a more realistic way of taking out a lot of enemies and making landmines and the like much much more practical usable in this game.Also, the game is quite short, which can be both a good and a bad thing in my opinion.

												Equipped with a sniper rifle, your protagonist must traverse through various WW II locales to eliminate high-ranking Nazi officials. The story gets interesting when you find out one of the officials is actually a traitor who has vital information as to what the Nazis are preparing for in their desperate attempt to turn the tides. This game is the epitome of long-range warfare! Sniping enemies has never been more fun! The Ghost Warrior games are nowhere near as exciting as Sniper Elite. The game regularly awards your long-distance, deadly shots with a slow-motion cutscene during which you can see the gory (and glorious) results of your doing. Quite often you get to see how the bones and organs are crushed within the enemies' bodies. Seeing how the heart of an MP40 wielding soldier explodes can be quite disgusting but also quite invigorating!Unfortunately, while the titular activity in this game is very well carried out everything else in the combat is quite mediocre. Close-combat fight can be quite difficult - it is next to impossible to get a headshot with an MP40 or a Thompson. It is as if the creators deliberately weakened all the other weapons just to force you to use the sniper rifle at all times. Not the mention the amount of bullets you have at your disposal - you will almost never run out of bullets while sniping. I get their point - still, a more refined system could have been put in place. I heard completing a major part of the game is possible via stealth gameplay - some of the achievements can only be obtained by taking this route. Still, I did not find the insta-kills interesting enough - I had several failed attempts due to the clunky movement of our character. Setting traps is also possible; we have tripmines, landmines and dynamites. Too bad it is quite rarely a must during the roughly 8-hour long campaign.Those of you who've already read my Nazi Zombie Army reviews must know how much I hate both games. I hate that you have an excellent idea but the execution is just horrible. Connecting to a host took ages and drops from the multiplayer game were frequent. With Sniper Elite V2's campaign I hate them even more as I can now see what levels the creators recycled to get their campaign ready. And now that I've mentioned the DLC titles I can confirm I did not find any cooperative / multiplayer sessions, at all. I expected this, though.Putting aside the non-existing online gameplay sessions Sniper Elite V2 offers a rather lengthy and great campaign. I do not know what can be more fun than taking out a tank by hitting its fuel tank with a well-aimed shot! This game is THE sniping game. Period!

												I picked this up on Steam in the "collection" version when it was on sale for a bit under $20. I've only been playing this for twenty-some odd hours now, but I really like it. I find myself replaying missions over and over chasing that perfect run, and trying out different tactics. Last night I played a mission pretty cleanly, and didn't get shot once so I got the "Hide and Hope" achievement. It felt like I had actually accomplished something! This game has reminded me of how much I like stealth mechanics, and slow, tactical gameplay. Now I've ordered other similar games for my library that I never played for some reason (Hitman series, Splintercell series). In fact, even though I'm less than half way through this campaign (and haven't played any of the coop), I went ahead and got Sniper Elite 3 and its season pass (together for $35, thanks internet!).The gameplay is very deliberate, if you like a run-n-gun style, this won't work for you. I really appreciate the tension and atmospherics in this game. Often even when I know I can safely run in a section, I will choose not to just because I hate making so much noise. Your sniper rifle is your best weapon. Your secondary has very limited range and accuracy, and also limited ammo on the battlefield (though there are strategies to improve this). You have to think like a sniper, don't shoot from a window, shoot from deep within the room, from the shadows (bonus, increased distance points!). Pulling off a perfect mission takes patience and strategy. Pulling it off with style takes experimentation and creativity (I pulled off the final stage of mission 4 using only traps last night). Maneuvering through the maps without ever being spotted is incredibly satisfying, and in some missions, incredibly difficult. Progressing your accuracy from all hits, to all headshots, to all through the eye or through the ear shots (beautifully confirmed by the amazing kill-cam) feels great. Doing that to 3-4 enemies in a row, all in a single breath feels amazing. This is really some kick♥♥♥♥♥sniping. And you can make it even more kick♥♥♥♥♥by tweaking the difficulty in a fairly flexible way. The in-game collectibles are completely meaningless, getting them all doesn't confer any kind of stat bonus or unlock new equipment, but I still like finding them as it satisfies that inner OCD (especially the bottles).The lack of a save system could be seen as a down side. It's checkpoint only. So if you screw something up, you may have to repeat a decent chunk, though they are usually pretty close together once you figure out the optimum pattern for a particular map.

												In Sniper Elite V2, you take the role of the worst marksman the collective allied powers could muster who is sent on a high-stakes covert mission by his superiors from within intellegence agencies to destroy progress Nazi superweapons, the V2 Rockets. You know. As a joke. To aid him, you gain access to a wide arsenal of submachineguns that your international assassin can just barely figure out which end is which on, pistols that are all broken and work improperly to some degree and high-power battle rifles with worn-out rifling, thousands and thousands of rounds of reduced power ammunition, and increasingly powerful optics made in the back of a moving truck that are incapable of any adjustment.Coincidentally, as you undergo your mission, the magnetic field of the earth becomes much more powerful in Europe. Thousands die. This forces the people of Europe to redesign their roadways to only go in straight lines though low-magnetism areas, so there is only one path throughout all of the missions. On top of this added challenge, your projectiles (which are low velocity to avoid radar detection) are being wrestled to the earth, clawing all well-made death machines to an estimation of 3,679 Minute of Angle accuracy. To make up for this handicap, though, your infantry rifles do have anti-tank capabilities and the majority of your opponents are firing at you with fire hoses filled with lead fishing weights.As far as the plot goes, it's your normal fare. It's a historic fiction game set between 1939 and 1945 very similar to others such as Medal of Honor, Call of Duty, etc. Now I have a bone to pick. These games all rip eachother off in their writing. Their characters all look the same, even have the same names, the games all take place at the same times in the same places. I mean, compare the main antagonist of this game, Adolf "Fuhrer" Hitler, to that of the Adolf Hitler character in any of the games I mentioned previously. What hacks. They even all have the same moustache. Is it really so hard to come up with your OWN setting? How about you call your war something other than "World War Two"? What about the first one? And why Germany? Why not something like Antagonistia or Detroit for a name? Some of the most uncreative writing I've ever found in a video game. Although, later in the game, I do like the twist where your character is bitten by a radioactive Nazi and gains x-ray vision, which reveals that the Nazis were really skeletons all along. It adds a nice twist to the setting and what I think would have actually happened were this a real war.I would recommend this game for young readers ages 8 to 12 who are hypoglycemic, get in excess of 40 hours of sleep a day, are multilingual, and have chronic vestigial flight capabilities.

												Finished Sniper Elite V2. Took me exactly 8 hours according to in-game statistics actually. A bit sooner than I expected but just the right time. It was getting tedious.It's a third-person shooter with a clear focus on long-range sniping, set in the last days of World War II. You play as a generic American sniper with the mission to eliminate five German rocket scientists before they can escape to Soviet Russia. This is it. This is the amount and depth of the story and characters. I don't remember a single name of the scientists or high-ranking German officers. I don't even remember my own name or if it was ever told. You could call it shallow, a backdrop or just not a focus of the devs which is fine because Sniper Elite V2 feels like a budget production, so it's natural for it to be lacking in visuals, polish and presentation in general.They did however put enough focus on what matters, the actual sniping. It is simply fun. What also makes it stand out is the gratuitous, excessive violence of the slow-motion x-ray kill-cam. It never got not satisfying to watch organs, skulls, gonads and bones get shredded.The game's structure is very straightforward with corridor-like maps that leave little room for different approaches. This surprised me as sniping could be done in a more open map design. It's not a detriment to the game though. This way missions take not too long and avert becoming tedious hunts. Besides your sniper rifle you also have a submachine gun and a pistol which will be used not as often. This is a good thing since close-quarters combat is lacking.On that front I feel the need to advise against a stealth playstyle. The mechanics are just not well implemented and the results are frustrating and unsatisfying. Once I abandoned stealth after the first few missions, my enjoyment with the game increased significantly. I feel the devs knew this as well, since there are no missions which have stealth requirements which is odd since there are stealth mechanics like carrying corpses, timing shots to ambient noise, visibility markers etc. They just don't work well on top of a lack of manual saving and bad, bad AI. As an action shooter it is a fun time.I do recommend giving this a try. Just leave any expectations of story at the door and prepare for a glorious shooting gallery.

												Sniper Elite V2 is a third person shooter that takes place during World War 2. The game is less of a run and gun shooter and more on stealth. I never did get into any multiplayer gaming and just played the solo campaign (I am not much for multiplay when the game offers an excellent campaign play through).I was one of the lucky people to get this game when Steam was offering it for free (for a 24 hour period) so I figured I would try the game out. Why not if its free right?I was impressed with the use of history and how it made for the story line during my first few minutes of play. I liked how the bullet cam worked as well. Taking aim at a very long shot after controlling your breathing then firing your rifle you will see your bullet travel all the way from your barrel to the target.What I was most impressed with was the X-Ray kill cam. At certain moments when you have a shot and fire you get an X-Ray of the target and get to see the skeleton and organs get damaged as the bullet travels through. Its pretty gruesome and for my first time seeing this I was amazed at the effects and coolness of it. I wouldn't say its true to life but well done for a video game.I didn't notice any issues with the game while playing but I did find that it relied on triggered events. For instance, I get in a building and hang back then use my sniper rifle scope to check the area ahead and don't notice anyone around. I fire a shot and nothing, so I creep up to the doorway and then the enemy's spawn.Setting yourself up to a vantage spot is very useful. In a solo campaign where you camp at a good spot and peg off anyone around is a good tactical move for playing a sniper in any game or any game mode.You do have other tools at your disposal like trip mines. Setting on up in a door way then heading up to the second floor and getting some kill shots off only to hear the trip wire go off makes me smile. Its an easy kill plus a good method to alert you to move to another spot.The main campaign story was also good. At the beginning of every mission there was a briefing as to the scenario to play out and what was needed to be done, all of it was voiced.I played the game with the Xbox 360 controller and Sniper Elite V2 is very friendly for controller support. I can't see myself playing this game with the keyboard and mouse.I have to admit this game was addicting and I did spend allot of time trying to get the X-Ray kill cam to happen. If it wasn't for that I don't think the game would offer all that much. The bullet cam is cool but its the X-Ray kill cam that really makes the game interesting.Now I got this game when it was free so I can't really say if its worth the price because when something is free of course its worth the price. However the game is currently $29.99 and although thats not a bad price I would wait till its on sale or the price drops to $9.99. You may also want to wait till the game and the DLC come bundled together for $29.99. Either way the game is fun and worth a play.Pro'sX-Ray kill camBullet CamIts a true Sniper gameVoiced mission briefingsDecent A.I.Con'sTriggered EventsHave to go through a couple menu's to finally exit out of the gameCVGAnton's Ratingːfirst_starːːfirst_starːːfirst_starːːfirst_starː

												Sniper Elite V2 is a bad case of a game trying to do what it isn't supposed to do. It markets itself as a sniper game. And I will admit it is very good at that. The sniping in the game is very satisfying and interesting. It's very fun trying to line up a good shot after factoring in the bullet drop and other factors. The slow motion and X-ray effects are great, they make you feel like you're powerful. Unfortunately, the game tries way too hard to be an action game at the same time. You spend more time sneaking around and shooting than sniping. Stealth plays an important part in the game, but it's done very poorly. There are no ways to easily kill guards silently, and your 'silent' crouch is extraordinarily slow. Simply put, stealth feels very sluggish and forced into the game. I found it a lot more satisfying just to pull out a gun and force my way through the stealth sections.Speaking of which, the gunplay in this game is awful. The camera controls don't work very well, and the guns feel completely useless. You feel like you're using a peashooter as the enemies shrug off bullets. No to mention there are way too many of these sections in the game. Why is it called "Sniper Elite" when you're using an SMG or pistol for 50% of the game?Overall the game is so terribly mediocre in all aspects I find it impossible to recommend. If you're looking for a really good stealth and sniping game, try the first game. But if you're looking for a competent game that doesn't bore the hell out of you, don't try this.

Posted: June 6, 2014
												Okay, if your favorite slice of the FPS pie is sniping, you might want to give this a go. I got it for free during a 24 hr Steam giveaway, but after having played it through I'd probably pay at least $10 for it. That's not much of a recommendation, but read on if you want to know why I take this particular stance. It's WW2, and you're a sniper working for American interests at the end of the war. The storyline is okay, not superb, but passable. Well, mostly--the ending is a bit much, but no spoilers here. You are fighting against German and Russian troops while attempting to keep V2 rocket technology from falling into Communist hands. Stock World War II characters and situations are prevalent with no memorable bad guys. I played through the entire solo campaign in less than 24 hours, and while certain battles and moments have stayed with me, a lot of it is fading into one long blur of FPS glory.The Good:The sniping can be, at times, truly amazing. The first time you breathe out and squeeze the trigger and watch the slow motion display of the carnage wrought by your well-aimed, well-timed shot, you will feel truly repulsed and rewarded at once. The usual sniping of FPS with either ragdoll physics or the flicking of a light switch effect that seem standard are largely replaced here by visuals that show bullet shattering bone, devastating internal organs, sparking off some metal gear being carried or worn, blowing a large exit wound in the opposite side of your foe, and the realistic tumble of an impacted round. As someone who was trained by the military in forensics and went on to work with one of the largest and most prominent medical examiners in the U.S. (Detroit produces a wealth of experience in forensic and autopsy work), I can say that I was impressed by a lot of what I saw. There are custom settings for different aspects of gameplay, so if one aspect doesn't suit you, you may be able to tinker with it; this includes difficulty of enemies, aiming assistance, and so on. There is a decent amount of variety in the types of objectives, maps, and situations you will encounter, so even though your play through may be somewhat brief, it shouldn't feel too repetitious. When you complete the solo campaign, there are multiplayer, co-op, and challenge modes available to extend replayability as well. What the developers got right, they got very right, and I can easily see myself coming back to this from time to time just to get some target and tactical practice.The Bad: The AI is awful. I found myself constructing many elaborate traps only to find I had no way to lure soldiers into them if they were beyond a certain distance. Not in every instance, but in far too many. And once you've set a trap, it's used. No way of retrieving them.You cannot shoot out lights. I find that nearly unforgivable in a game like this. Also, there are bottles set up for target shooting, but apparently they are made of some incredible material because you can't knock over or destroy them from 5 feet away with a handgun. Only sniper rifles can destroy them, which brings unwanted attention of course. Also, the mutant regeneration ability seems out of place, even if it is necessary to the game's mechanics of play. Not saying it is, just saying. And it seems silly, even if satisfying, to be able to destroy all manner of vehicles with a single, well-aimed shot, but not be able to shoot out a lightbulb.The Ugly:Multiplayer. Take out the one thing that makes this game worth getting, toss in lackluster maps which, at least in some instances, are clearly imbalanced in favor of one team over the other, and return to everything that is tired and old about WW2 FPS games, and that's the multiplayer I experienced in the three servers I joined. Nothing there to keep me coming back. Oh, and don't forget the players who've memorized the best spots on the best side for each map to absolutely make the play monotonous and frustrating beyond belief. I've played much older games in this genre that did a much better job of it. I have not tried co-op yet (UPDATE: this has changed), and I'm hoping it will offer something more than multiplayer. Oh, and before I go (I edited to add this part), the stealth aspect. It's almost non-existant. There are moments when you can use it, but for a sniping game those moments are far too few. Most of the time you'll feel like Rambo, but with a sniper rifle instead of an M-60. I wish they had made this more of a true stealth game, but alas...Final Analysis:Decent fun for the price, if you catch it free or for cheap. If you like sniping, give it a shot. Just don't expect too much out of this title and it'll be alright. If you have a buddy who likes this game, co-op is alright even if somewhat limited and at times redundant. I like it even with its faults.

												Sniper Elite V2 can be a great game, but with many flaws.  First of all the AI is extremely poor, I found most soldiers could be baited and tunneled with ease, not to mention lured into the "pill box" for a line-up of kills. content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												SPOILERS AHEAD.Sniper Elite V2 is a rare breed. A WWII game, but with an emphasis on stealth rather than the usual guns blazing tactic seen in other FPS and TPS war games. You play as Karl Fairburne, an American sniper sent into Berlin during the dying throes of WWII to assassinate German rocket scientists.The main feature of the game, the sniping, is pretty damn good. The bullet cam mechanic is one of the most varied I've seen, unrivalled in realistic shooters, and the only one rivalling it in any shooter maybe being Stranglehold's Precision Aim mechanic. However, on higher difficulty levels, the bullet ballistics and wind mechanics can be fiddly at it's worst, but I find it gives you an amazing high when you can calculate the exact place to shoot, slotting a fresh round from a Gewehr 43 into some Nazi's frontal lobe.Speaking of which, the guns in this game can be described in one word: beautiful. They stay faithful to the real world counterparts, sharing the names and both the pros and cons, with the Mosin-Nagant's bolt-action reload slowing down your killfest in return for astounding bullet velocity, and the PPSh-41 trading ammo in some places for a higher fire-rate. On lower video qualities, the guns look slightly blocky, but on higher, they look just like the real variants.-- SPOILERS START HERE --The story, although contrived at times, is a nice backdrop to your bloodlust. As Karl Fairburne, you are tasked with eliminating multiple German rocket scientists, although there are many ways the game surprises you with this, including attempting to save one as he defects to the American side. It is revealled that as a last ditch attempt to win the war for the Axis, the Germans and the Russians are planning to use V2 rockets aimed at London and filled with deadly Tabun gas. Eventually you shut down the V2 launch site and assassinate the mastermind.If this sounds all a bit gung-ho, that's because it is. Although Sniper Elite V2 is a great stealth game, deep down inside, it wants to be like Battlefield, it wants to be like CoD, it wants to play with the big boys. The story has been altered from the original Sniper Elite back in 2005, to adjust for the changing times. In the original, you have assistance from the German resistance. This has been taken out of V2, as a large section of FPS fans these days prefer a "lone wolf" type story. Some of the in-game areas are a bit too close quarters for what's meant to be a stealthy sniping game, including the Russian HQ in East Berlin, where a large amount of enemies (probably around 20 or so) come screaming at you down a narrow-ish corridor.However, on the majority of the game, it is a bona fide departure from the Modern Warfares and Bad Companies that populate the FPS genre these days. Sniper Elite V2 is a healthy apple in a Happy Meal of double cheeseburgers and McNuggets. Overall, I do recommend this game, and would suggest it to not only the more discerning gamer, but even your average teenager with a 10 second attention span.9/10 - could have improved in some places, but overall a gem. Pick it up if you see it on sale at any time, or even if you just have spare dosh lying around.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												Sniper Elite V2 puts you into the WWII setting in Berlin, 1941. You obviously should play the first game before this, but some of you didn't, which I'm guilty of too. I feel that after playing the first 3 missions of the game, the review was ready to be spit out. I personally like this game, and the reasons so I will say. Now the gameplay is very nice, giving you a challenge the whole way through the mission, which I like. Unlike COD, this game takes the use of your brain and putting it to work. You can't run in throught the mission and shoot, hell no, not in this game. You can easily die running into the mission, which I'm guilty of the first couple times. You can easily be picked off by one or two enemys by running in, but in COD you can take on 10-15, which is insanely absurd. Which is mainly why I don't like COD too much, but the zombies mode and campaign are alright. So, in order to not get killed so much is to have the enemy come to you, you don't come to them because 2-3 shots can kill you right off the bat.Now to talk about the graphics and the enviroment. The enviroment is great, it gives that vibe to the whole WWII scene, having to do with flying planes, destroyed buildings, tanks, roadblocks, exploded vehicles, you name it, the game has it. The graphics are beautiful, running Sniper Elite on a 1080p resolution and the ultra settings preset made this game look beautiful, which contributed to the game being so good to me personally. But, the water and smoke looks like poop! The water looks like a plastic sheet put over the ground, not to mention that stepping in it had no splashing effect which made the water so lifeless like it wasn't even water. The game developers need to put some physics into the water and smoke, or it'll just make the enviroment seem more lifeless and bland. The smoke from a far distance looks good, but up close it looks like it was made with the Microsoft default Paint program you have in the Start menu. The smoke also has no density to it, making it bland just like the water. Again, the developers should've spent more time on the smoke and water effects. Anyways, I forgive it since the rest of the enviroment looks next-gen with great PC optimization giving a full 60FPS on ultra with this last-gen GeForce GTX 550 Ti Gigabyte OC that I carry in this PC.Now the background story, which this game doesn't really have any. The backstory to this game makes me say "What"? Now, what I mean is that there's no backstory to this game, as in the cutscenes before each mission for example Grand Theft Auto, Half-Life, and Mafia II have a backstory, which gives it's background that promotes the fuller understanding of the game, although there's a brief saying of the mission you are about to enter in this game. But, still there really isn't a backstory to the game. Now, if you don't understand what a game's "backstory" is, I'd go look up backstory on Google or whatever search engine you use. Anyways, Sniper Elite is still good even though it has its flaws to the game. Every game has its flaws. Like Grand Theft Auto IV, which has sort of a horrible PC optimization to the game.The heartbeat system consists of mainly two things, your lung capacity to use focus time, and your health. When your heartrate goes above 80BPM you can't go into focus time, there's two reasons as to why it is over 80BPM. One: You've been shot, which brings up the heartrate, but not necessarily all the time though, there's a few times when I been hit 3 times and it still was at 70BPM. Two: You've have been either jogging or running around, which would always raise your heartrate. So, that's the heartrate system in a nutshell.HUD elements like your objective and your weapon and ammo will disappear after an amount of about 5 seconds, which can be helpful if you need to see at the corners of your screen. That's a plus in any game.Overall, the game's nice, the music is good. The gunshots are satisfying when you snipe someone overhead. The overall rating of this game is a good 8.7/10.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												My rate for this game is 6 out of 10, that means "If you enjoy sniping and planting explosive traps and you have nothing better to do you may find this game entertaining". At least that's the spirit how I played it.So, I actually won't un-recommend it because it doesn't deserve it but surely it deserves critics.Because this game is wrong from the basis: it is supposed to be a "stealth game" but it is clearly not; a "sniping game" but sniper rifle isn't the most useful weapon; a "realistic game" and it is definitely not!Before explaining my critics let me tell in advice that i played at the highest difficulty. So, let's start with the stealth factor.I won't definite this a stealth game because you can't complete any level stealthly. Well, actually you can't complete any ROOM stealthly: The only stealthy weapon you have is a silenced pistol that is way the most useful weapon of the game (But "Silenced-Pistoler elitè V2" didn't sound good enough); then you have an un-suppressed sniper rifle who aggros enemy just by pointing them (if you point them with the binoculars you will not be caught that easily); and a nice arsenal of explosives. It doesn't sound like a very quite equipment.In game you fight against troopers, and snipers: the latter will shoot at you anyway (so there's no need for stealth) the firsts don't act at all like a real trained soldier: no one soldier will "pound the alarm", not even after an explosion (that's why to this game sound logical give landmines as a stealty weapon). Any un-quite action will only alarm the soldiers in nearby: it doesn't matter if you shoot away everything, blast them with grenades, or snipe efficently: you will never be in permanent trouble.Also, if a soldier finds a dead body he doesn't pound the alarm of call for reinforcements (there's no such a thing in this game) he just stays close to the body, wondering what could this mean.If you try instead to move the body you will alarm the enemy because you are being loud.So: leaving a body is not a negative beavior because it doesn't get you in trouble, actually is a POSITIVE beavior because you can fill the body with mines. Stealth. Sniper.Another example of the lack of logic is the tank AI. They act like dogs. Indeed, like dogs: If a tank see you it will shoot cannonballs as long as you are in his line of sight, than it just go away. Like a dog barking to defend its territory.Oh, yes, and of course a tank shooting does not alarm nearby soldiers.Another disturbing element is that the game gives you an arsenal for a preparatory game: you should know the territory, what will happen, then you plant mines and choose your position accordingly. But this never happens: you just follow the track, snipe the main target (or snipe some explosives, just to remain stealth) from a position unknown from the beginning, and at last you fight your way out without knowing in advice what way will be.So: what's the point with mines?I think the game is the result of a developing team that didn't follow the same line guide: some one wanted to make a stealth game, and some one other said that didn't sell enought.

Posted: March 10, 2014
												I love this game. Its bullet physics, and the visceral impact the game displays to you is all awesome, and probably worth the purchase alone at the right price.  However, instead of presenting you with a lot interesting sharpshooter scenarios, the game tends to put you more into a meat grinder, by throwing wave after wave of enemies at you.  There were a few times during the game where I had to make a complex shot on my target.  Those instances were fun.  But, they only lasted maybe 2 minutes a piece.  The rest of the game revolves around shooting Nazi A, Nazi B, or Nazi C, (or Russian A, Russian B, or Russian C).  It stops being a sniper game, and becomes a standard shooter.  The times where I had to time my shots to coincide with artillery shells exploding were awesome.  There needs to be more intersting things like that.  Or, if they are going to force me into a building to retrieve a document, I would like to have some sort of melee or takedown option because I always favor stealth over guns blazing.  Overall, now that I have thought about it enough while writing this review, the game is kind of cheap.  Which can make the awesome bullet cam seem like a gimmick.  I can see how someone would think the entire game was basically that, and the rest is just cheap window dressing (i.e. great bullet cam... lame story, cheap enemies, meat grinder missions, poor voice overs, repetive music).  I'm a little torn on this game, but I can't recommend it.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												Let me start out by saying this: I own this game for the 360 and have put dozens of hours into it. I've beat it multiple times and have gone back to redo levels just for fun. When the giveaway for this popped up, I couldn't wait to have another copy for PC.This game is my favorite shooter of all time, and I play a lot of them between twelve separate game systems. There is endless replayability in this game...this is the type of game where if you mess up and die, it really doesn't bother you, because it's so much freaking fun to go back through it again and again. Obviously, the game is centered around being a sniper during World War II, though you also have other methods of killing Nazis at your disposal, including a silenced pistol, mines, etc. You can play this game any way you want. If you'd like to go for stealth, you can try timing your sniper shots with the soundwaves of nearby explosions, sirens, etc. so that you remain undetected, all while hiding bodies. OR, you could rush into situations, hole up in a room, set some traps at the door and wait for the Nazis to come to you. Ideally, you'll want to settle somewhere in the middle, but the fact that you are free to choose how to progress is liberating.The bullet cam pushes this game over the line from "superb" to "awesometacular." For many of your sniper bullets, the camera will follow your bullet and slow down time, showing you exactly how well you aimed your shot by offering to you an "inside the body" view of the damage your bullet does to an unfortunate Nazi. If you get a headshot where your bullet explodes an eye, it shows you that. The gore, while present, is also realistic. It's not over-the-top to be over-the-top, but it is oddly and disturbingly satisfying. I can't count the numbers of times I've yelled out loud, "NICE!" or "Did I get the eye? Did I get the eye? YESSSS!!!" Trust me...you'll be doing this often, as this game makes you feel like an absolute badass.Finally, the environments are varied and interesting. You'll be going through streets full of ruined homes, cities on fire, having sniper battles on rooftops (my favorite mission)...not to mention they also offer two types of collectibles that are actually fun to search for. I'm a "game collectible" fiend, and this game does it best, in my opinion, over any other game with collectibles that I've ever played. One of the collectibles is a brown bottle that each level has a set amount of. You have to shoot them to collect them, so you'll be having a lot of fun finding these in hidden, far off places, on the map or off. Also, these bottles are hidden well. You can tell the devs had a ton of fun hiding them in ridiculous places, rather than just putting them in corners and calling it a day.In summary, this game is a god among games. It does everything right, and adds some interesting and original ideas to the genre...a genre already unfortunately low in sniper-focused games. I only preorder about one game every few years...and this is the game that convinced me to make that game Sniper Elite 3, because this game is just untouchable. This is a game you will play and replay just for the pure entertainment value. If you don't have it yet, buy it. You won't regret it.

												You play as a sniper in World War II setting. During that era, silencer for sniper rifle aren't invented yet, so to achieve stealth kills using sniper rifle, you will need to time your shot with environmental noise like bomb shells or thunder storm.The concept is not bad, but in practise, it is very hard to achieve stealth. It is very easy to trigger alarm, and once it is triggered, the entire sector will instantly know where you are and fire at you.You can lay traps and lure approaching enemies to it, but it is very ineffective and troublesome to setup, and some times it will still trigger alarm anyway.So on overall, unless you are very patience, more than half of the time this game can be treated as a generic shooter, with sniper rifle as primary weapon.But, if you are very patience, and like to play it correctly as a stealth game where you carefully plan your route, and scout the area, this game might really suit your taste.The graphics are not bad. Kill cams are awesome! For some time. It gets dull and repetitive very soon. The plot is not bad.The entire campaign can be played in coop.Review for DLCsEach DLC adds one extra mission, all are in one single giant map. These DLC missions can only be played in single player.Story and setting-wise, they are quite okay. Pricing is okay too as a DLC, so get them if you liked the game.For Achievement HuntersThe following DLCs are required for 100% completion.St. Pierre DLCThe Neudorf Outpost PackThe Landwehr Canal PackMost of the achievements are quite doable. But some of the harder ones require some luck, and a huge lot of patience.My score: 7/10
